docs.text: Magnetic Field # Field around a wire # B = \frac{\mu_0}{2\pi} \frac{I}{r} B = \frac{\mu_0}{2\pi} \frac{I}{r} Force # Use right hand rule to determine direction of force. Moving particle # F_M = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}\\ \color{grey} F_M = \lvert q\vec{v} \rvert \lvert sin(\theta) \rvert \lvert \vec{B} \rvert F_M = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}\\ \color{grey} F_M = \lvert q\vec{v} \rvert \lvert sin(\theta) \rvert \lvert \vec{B} \rvert Current-carrying wire # F_M = I\vec{l} \times B\\ \color{grey} F_M = \lvert I\vec{l} \rvert \lvert sin(\theta) \rvert \lvert \vec{B} \rvert F_M = I\vec{l} \times B\\ \color{grey} F_M = \lvert I\vec{l} \rvert \lvert sin(\theta) \rvert \lvert \vec{B} \rvert Magnetic Flux # \Phi_B = \vec{B} \cdot \vec{A}\\ \color{grey} \Phi_B = \lvert \vec{B} \rvert cos(\theta) \lvert \vec{A} \rvert\\ \Phi_B = \vec{B} \cdot \vec{A}\\ \color{grey} \Phi_B = \lvert \vec{B} \rvert cos(\theta) \lvert \vec{A} \rvert\\ Electromotive Force # \mathcal{E} = - \frac{\Delta\Phi_B}{\Delta t}\\ \mathcal{E} = \vec{B}lv \mathcal{E} = - \frac{\Delta\Phi_B}{\Delta t}\\ \mathcal{E} = \vec{B}lv Use with Ohm's Law to find the current induced by magnetic field.
docs.title: Magnetic Field

docs.text: B = \frac{\mu_0}{2\pi} \frac{I}{r} B = \frac{\mu_0}{2\pi} \frac{I}{r}
docs.title: Field around a wire

docs.title: Magnetic Flux

docs.text: \mathcal{E} = - \frac{\Delta\Phi_B}{\Delta t}\\ \mathcal{E} = \vec{B}lv \mathcal{E} = - \frac{\Delta\Phi_B}{\Delta t}\\ \mathcal{E} = \vec{B}lv Use with Ohm's Law to find the current induced by magnetic field.
docs.title: Electromotive Force

docs.text: Circuits # Resistors # Resistance is measured in ohms ( \Omega \Omega ). Resistivity # R = \frac{\rho l}{A} R = \frac{\rho l}{A} Equivalent Resistance # R_s = \sum_{i} {R_i}\\ \frac{1}{R_p} = \sum_{i} {\frac{1}{R_i}} R_s = \sum_{i} {R_i}\\ \frac{1}{R_p} = \sum_{i} {\frac{1}{R_i}} Capacitors # Capacitance is measured in farads (F). Capacitance # C = \kappa\epsilon_0\frac{A}{d} = \frac{Q}{V}\\ U_C = \frac{1}{2} Q\Delta{V} = \frac{1}{2} C(\Delta{V})^2\\ \epsilon_0 = 8.85\times10^{-12} \enspace C^2 / N \cdot m^2 C = \kappa\epsilon_0\frac{A}{d} = \frac{Q}{V}\\ U_C = \frac{1}{2} Q\Delta{V} = \frac{1}{2} C(\Delta{V})^2\\ \epsilon_0 = 8.85\times10^{-12} \enspace C^2 / N \cdot m^2 Vacuum permittivity ( \epsilon_0 \epsilon_0 ) is always constant. Dielectric constant \kappa \kappa depends on the material between the plates and doesn't have any units. Equivalent Capacitance # \frac{1}{C_s} = \sum_{i} {\frac{1}{C_i}}\\ C_p = \sum_{i} {C_i} \frac{1}{C_s} = \sum_{i} {\frac{1}{C_i}}\\ C_p = \sum_{i} {C_i} Equivalent capacitance is the opposite of equivalent resistance. Charge, Discharge # \tau = R * C\\ \color{grey} V_c = V_s (1 - e^{-\frac{t}{RC}}) \tau = R * C\\ \color{grey} V_c = V_s (1 - e^{-\frac{t}{RC}}) Capacitor charge and discharge are exponential, so at one time constant \tau \tau , the capacitor has charged or discharged by 63%. After 5\tau 5\tau seconds, charging is virtually complete. Electricity # V = IR\\ P = IV\\ I = \frac{\Delta{Q}}{\Delta{t}}\\ I = \frac{\Delta{V}}{R} V = IR\\ P = IV\\ I = \frac{\Delta{Q}}{\Delta{t}}\\ I = \frac{\Delta{V}}{R}
docs.title: Circuits

Dielectric constant \kappa \kappa depends on the material between the plates and doesn't have any units.

After 5\tau 5\tau seconds, charging is virtually complete.

docs.text: V = IR\\ P = IV\\ I = \frac{\Delta{Q}}{\Delta{t}}\\ I = \frac{\Delta{V}}{R} V = IR\\ P = IV\\ I = \frac{\Delta{Q}}{\Delta{t}}\\ I = \frac{\Delta{V}}{R}
docs.title: Electricity

docs.text: Electric Field, Force, and Potential # Tip The best way to remember these equations is the Electricity Diamond. Force # \vec{F} = \frac{kQ_1q_2}{r^2} = \vec{E}q_2 \color{grey} = \frac{U}{r} = \frac{Vq_2}{r} \vec{F} = \frac{kQ_1q_2}{r^2} = \vec{E}q_2 \color{grey} = \frac{U}{r} = \frac{Vq_2}{r} Field # \vec{E} = \frac{kQ_1}{r^2} = \frac{\vec{F}}{q_2} = \frac{V}{r} \color{grey} = \frac{U}{q_2r} \vec{E} = \frac{kQ_1}{r^2} = \frac{\vec{F}}{q_2} = \frac{V}{r} \color{grey} = \frac{U}{q_2r} Energy # U = \frac{kQ_1q_2}{r} = \vec{F}r = Vq_2 \color{grey} = \vec{E}q_2r U = \frac{kQ_1q_2}{r} = \vec{F}r = Vq_2 \color{grey} = \vec{E}q_2r Electric Potential # V =\frac{kQ_1}{r} = \vec{E}r = \frac{U}{q} \color{grey} = \frac{\vec{F}r}{q_2} V =\frac{kQ_1}{r} = \vec{E}r = \frac{U}{q} \color{grey} = \frac{\vec{F}r}{q_2}
docs.title: Electric Field

docs.text: Tip The best way to remember these equations is the Electricity Diamond.
docs.title: Electric Field, Force, and Potential

docs.text: \vec{F} = \frac{kQ_1q_2}{r^2} = \vec{E}q_2 \color{grey} = \frac{U}{r} = \frac{Vq_2}{r} \vec{F} = \frac{kQ_1q_2}{r^2} = \vec{E}q_2 \color{grey} = \frac{U}{r} = \frac{Vq_2}{r}
docs.title: Force

docs.text: \vec{E} = \frac{kQ_1}{r^2} = \frac{\vec{F}}{q_2} = \frac{V}{r} \color{grey} = \frac{U}{q_2r} \vec{E} = \frac{kQ_1}{r^2} = \frac{\vec{F}}{q_2} = \frac{V}{r} \color{grey} = \frac{U}{q_2r}
docs.title: Field

docs.text: U = \frac{kQ_1q_2}{r} = \vec{F}r = Vq_2 \color{grey} = \vec{E}q_2r U = \frac{kQ_1q_2}{r} = \vec{F}r = Vq_2 \color{grey} = \vec{E}q_2r
docs.title: Energy

docs.text: V =\frac{kQ_1}{r} = \vec{E}r = \frac{U}{q} \color{grey} = \frac{\vec{F}r}{q_2} V =\frac{kQ_1}{r} = \vec{E}r = \frac{U}{q} \color{grey} = \frac{\vec{F}r}{q_2}
docs.title: Electric Potential

docs.text: Fluids # Buoyancy # Buoyant Force # F_B = \rho_fV_{disp}g F_B = \rho_fV_{disp}g Buoyancy depends on density of the fluid and the displacing volume of the object. When an object is floating, F_B F_B is equal to the force of gravity. Flow # AP fluids are generally assumed to be incompressible and have no turbulence/friction, so flow rate/continuity is useful. Flow Rate # Q = \frac{V}{\Delta t}\\ Q = \frac{lA}{\Delta t}\\ Q = vA Q = \frac{V}{\Delta t}\\ Q = \frac{lA}{\Delta t}\\ Q = vA Flow Continuity Equation # Q_1 = v_1a_1 = v_2a_2 = Q_2 Q_1 = v_1a_1 = v_2a_2 = Q_2 Bernoulli's Equation # P_1 - P_2 = \frac{1}{2} \rho \left(v_2^2 - v_1^2\right) + \rho g\left(y_2 - y_1\right) P_1 - P_2 = \frac{1}{2} \rho \left(v_2^2 - v_1^2\right) + \rho g\left(y_2 - y_1\right) Useful conservation of energy form # P_1 + \rho gy_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = P_2 + \rho gy_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2 P_1 + \rho gy_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = P_2 + \rho gy_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2
docs.title: Fluids

docs.text: F_B = \rho_fV_{disp}g F_B = \rho_fV_{disp}g Buoyancy depends on density of the fluid and the displacing volume of the object. When an object is floating, F_B F_B is equal to the force of gravity.
docs.title: Buoyant Force

docs.text: AP fluids are generally assumed to be incompressible and have no turbulence/friction, so flow rate/continuity is useful.
docs.title: Flow

docs.text: Q = \frac{V}{\Delta t}\\ Q = \frac{lA}{\Delta t}\\ Q = vA Q = \frac{V}{\Delta t}\\ Q = \frac{lA}{\Delta t}\\ Q = vA
docs.title: Flow Rate

docs.text: P_1 - P_2 = \frac{1}{2} \rho \left(v_2^2 - v_1^2\right) + \rho g\left(y_2 - y_1\right) P_1 - P_2 = \frac{1}{2} \rho \left(v_2^2 - v_1^2\right) + \rho g\left(y_2 - y_1\right)
docs.title: Bernoulli's Equation

docs.text: P_1 + \rho gy_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = P_2 + \rho gy_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2 P_1 + \rho gy_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = P_2 + \rho gy_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2
docs.title: Useful conservation of energy form

docs.text: Thermodynamics # First Law of Thermodynamics # \Delta U = Q + W \Delta U = Q + W Heat/Energy Equations # The big daddy of thermo # U = \frac{1}{2}mv_{rms}^2 = \frac{3}{2}Nk_BT = \frac{3}{2}nRT = \frac{3}{2}PV U = \frac{1}{2}mv_{rms}^2 = \frac{3}{2}Nk_BT = \frac{3}{2}nRT = \frac{3}{2}PV This equation is derived from the kinetic energy of a single molecule and the ideal gas law. Specific heat # Q = mc\Delta T Q = mc\Delta T Temperature to raise mass m m of substance with specific heat c c , \Delta T \Delta T degrees. If there is a phase change, then you need to calculate the energy for that with the latent heat equation. Latent heat # Q_F = mL_F \\ Q_V = mL_V Q_F = mL_F \\ Q_V = mL_V Use latent heat equations to calculate energy required for phase changes (fusion or vaporization). Efficiency # e = \frac{Q_H - Q_C}{Q_H} = \frac{W}{Q_H} e = \frac{Q_H - Q_C}{Q_H} = \frac{W}{Q_H} Ideal efficiency (Carnot Engine) # e_c = \frac{T_H - T_C}{T_H} = 1 - \frac{T_C}{T_H} e_c = \frac{T_H - T_C}{T_H} = 1 - \frac{T_C}{T_H} For a Carnot engine, the efficiency can be determined by the temperatures of the heat reservoirs because of entropy or something. Heat transfer rate (conduction) # \frac{Q}{\Delta t} = \frac{kA\Delta T}{L} \frac{Q}{\Delta t} = \frac{kA\Delta T}{L} "It's just an equation"
docs.title: Thermodynamics

docs.text: \Delta U = Q + W \Delta U = Q + W
docs.title: First Law of Thermodynamics

docs.text: U = \frac{1}{2}mv_{rms}^2 = \frac{3}{2}Nk_BT = \frac{3}{2}nRT = \frac{3}{2}PV U = \frac{1}{2}mv_{rms}^2 = \frac{3}{2}Nk_BT = \frac{3}{2}nRT = \frac{3}{2}PV This equation is derived from the kinetic energy of a single molecule and the ideal gas law.
docs.title: The big daddy of thermo

docs.text: Q = mc\Delta T Q = mc\Delta T Temperature to raise mass m m of substance with specific heat c c , \Delta T \Delta T degrees. If there is a phase change, then you need to calculate the energy for that with the latent heat equation.
docs.title: Specific heat

docs.title: Latent heat

docs.text: e = \frac{Q_H - Q_C}{Q_H} = \frac{W}{Q_H} e = \frac{Q_H - Q_C}{Q_H} = \frac{W}{Q_H}
docs.title: Efficiency

docs.text: e_c = \frac{T_H - T_C}{T_H} = 1 - \frac{T_C}{T_H} e_c = \frac{T_H - T_C}{T_H} = 1 - \frac{T_C}{T_H} For a Carnot engine, the efficiency can be determined by the temperatures of the heat reservoirs because of entropy or something.
docs.title: Ideal efficiency (Carnot Engine)
